{{Use British English|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Lee Tomlin | image = Lee Tomlin 27-08-2016 1.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Tomlin playing for [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in 2016 | fullname = Lee Marc Tomlin{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-professional-retain-list--free-transfers---2017-18.pdf |title=Club list of registered players: As at 19th May 2018: Cardiff City |publisher=English Football League |format=PDF |page=12 |accessdate=17 June 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|1|12|df=y}}{{cite book |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2006–07 |year=2006 |publisher=Mainstream Publishing |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-1-84596-111-4 |page=406}} | birth_place = [[Leicester]], England | height = {{height|ft=5|in=11}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Striker]] / [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|Attacking midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Peterborough United F.C.| Peterborough United]]
(on loan from [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]) | clubnumber = 29 | youthyears1 = 1996–2005 | youthclubs1 = [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] | youthyears2 = 2005 | youthclubs2 = [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]] | years1 = 2005–2010 | clubs1 = [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]] | caps1 = 156 | goals1 = 27 | years2 = 2007 | clubs2 = → [[Brackley Town F.C.|Brackley Town]] (loan) | caps2 = 2 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2010–2014 | clubs3 = [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] | caps3 = 135 | goals3 = 32 | years4 = 2014–2015 | clubs4 = [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] | caps4 = 56 | goals4 = 11 | years5 = 2015–2016 | clubs5 = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] | caps5 = 6 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2016 | clubs6 = → [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] (loan) | caps6 = 18 | goals6 = 6 | years7 = 2016–2017 | clubs7 = [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] | caps7 = 38 | goals7 = 6 | years8 = 2017– | clubs8 = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | caps8 = 13 | goals8 = 1 | years9 = 2018 | clubs9 = → [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] (loan) | caps9 = 15 | goals9 = 4 | years10 = 2019– | clubs10 = → [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] (loan) | caps10 = 4 | goals10 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2009 | nationalteam1 = [[England national football C team|England C]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 15:16, 30 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Lee Marc Tomlin''' (born 12 January 1989) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|striker]] or as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]] for [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]], on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]. ==Early life== Tomlin was born in [[Leicester]], [[Leicestershire]]. He started his career with the [[youth system]] of [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in 1996 before joining [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]]'s youth system in 2005.{{cite web |title=Career history |url=http://www.uptheposh.com/people/523/career/ |work=Up The Posh! |accessdate=20 January 2017}} In October 2005, he became Rushden's youngest ever [[first-team]] player when he came on as a [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Drewe Broughton]] in the 74th minute.{{cite news |title=Posh swoop for Lee Tomlin |url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/sport/football/posh/posh-swoop-for-lee-tomlin-1-797656 |newspaper=Peterborough Today |date=7 August 2010 |accessdate=20 January 2017}} Throughout the rest of the season he made several more substitute appearances, but his first start came in November 2005, in an FA Cup first round replay against [[Halifax Town A.F.C.|Halifax Town]]. He made 21 appearances in [[EFL League Two|League Two]] in the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season. ==Club career== ===Early career=== Before the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07]] season, Tomlin attracted the attention of several big clubs and he earned a trial with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].{{cite news |title=Rushden teenager in Anfield trial |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rushden_and_diamonds/4869702.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 April 2006 |accessdate=27 September 2010}} Throughout the season, he made more starts and became more of a regular in the Rushden starting eleven. He scored his first goal for the club against [[Weymouth F.C.|Weymouth]], the match after [[Paul Hart]] was sacked, in the 21st minute.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} He immediately followed this with another goal, this time against [[Altrincham F.C.|Altrincham]] in the [[FA Cup]] fourth qualifying round.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} He scored six goals during the season, playing as a forward and on both wings.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} Tomlin joined [[Southern Football League|Southern League]] Premier Division club Brackley Town in October 2007 on a one-month [[Loan (sports)|loan]],{{cite news |title=Tomlin joins Brackley on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rushden_and_diamonds/7045120.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 October 2007 |accessdate=20 January 2017}} making two appearances. Tomlin switched to left midfield for the [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10]] season, under his influential manager [[Justin Edinburgh]] whom he credited for his development and achieving his move to the Football League.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} Following the end of the season a six-figure bid for Tomlin was rejected from another Blue Square Bet Premier club believed to be [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] and Rushden confirmed he would be offered a new contract.{{cite news |title=Rushden & Diamonds to offer Lee Tomlin new deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rushden_and_diamonds/8793487.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 July 2010 |accessdate=6 July 2010}} ===Peterborough United=== [[File:Lee Tomlin.jpg|thumb|upright|Tomlin playing for [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] in 2012]] Tomlin signed for [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] for an undisclosed fee on 6 August 2010.{{cite web | title = Posh swoop for highly-rated Tomlin | url = http://www.theposh.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10427~2113869,00.html | publisher = Peterborough United F.C. | date = 6 August 2010 | accessdate = 6 August 2010}} He went on to assist the team gain promotion with a hard working display against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] at [[Old Trafford]], which The Posh won 3–0.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} He continued to develop his reputation at Championship level and on 20 August 2011, he scored his first professional [[hat-trick]] in a game against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], helping Peterborough to a 7–1 win.{{cite news |title=Peterborough 7–1 Ipswich |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/14514657 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 August 2011 |accessdate=20 January 2017}} Tomlin beat five defenders to score in Peterborough's last game of the [[2012–13 Football League Championship|2012–13 season]], away to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], but a 3–2 defeat confirmed their relegation back to League One.{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Crystal Palace 3–2 Peterborough |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22320597 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 May 2013 |accessdate=20 January 2017}} ===Middlesbrough=== On 31 January 2014, Tomlin signed for [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] on loan for the remainder of the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|2013–14]] season with a view to a permanent move.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} On 18 February, it was announced that he had signed permanently on a three-and-a-half-year contract.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} Tomlin made his debut on 22 February in a 0–0 draw against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], coming on as a substitute for [[Kei Kamara]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} After a run of fine performances, most notable in Middlesbrough's 2–0 victory over Manchester City in the FA Cup, Tomlin was named [[Football League Championship Player of the Month|Championship Player of the Month]] for January 2015.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} ===Bournemouth=== On 4 August 2015, Tomlin signed for [[Premier League]] newcomers [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on a three-year deal for a fee of around £3.5 million.{{Cite news |title=Lee Tomlin signs for AFC Bournemouth from Middlesbrough |url=http://www.afcb.co.uk/news/article/lee-tomlin-signs-for-afc-bournemouth-from-middlesbrough-2593599.aspx |publisher=AFC Bournemouth |date=4 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229184729/http://www.afcb.co.uk/news/article/lee-tomlin-signs-for-afc-bournemouth-from-middlesbrough-2593599.aspx/ |archivedate=29 December 2016 |df=dmy-all }} He made his debut against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], coming on for [[Joshua King (footballer)|Joshua King]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} He scored his only goal for Bournemouth in the [[2015–16 Premier League|2015–16 season]], a penalty against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in the [[FA Cup]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} ===Bristol City=== Tomlin signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club, [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on a season-long loan, on 27 January 2016.{{cite news |title=Lee Tomlin: Bristol City sign Bournemouth midfielder on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35421741 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 January 2016}} He later made his debut in a goalless draw against Birmingham City on 30 January.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} Tomlin went onto score 6 goals in 18 appearances, including goals in a 6–0 win over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] and a 4–0 win over Huddersfield Town.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} During the summer, Tomlin opened talks with Bristol City and took part in a medical on 4 July.{{cite news |title=Bristol City: Bournemouth's Lee Tomlin to have medical at Ashton Gate |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36703823 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 July 2016}} ===Cardiff City=== On 13 July 2017, Tomlin joined [[Football League Championship|Championship]] rivals [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on a three-year contact for an undisclosed fee,{{cite news |title=Lee Tomlin signs for the Bluebirds |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2017/july/lee-tomlin-signs-for-bluebirds/ |publisher=Cardiff City FC |date=13 July 2017}} making his debut for the club on the opening day of the 2017–18 season during a 1–0 victory over [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40760771 |title=Burton Albion 0–1 Cardiff City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 August 2017 |accessdate=5 August 2017}} On 31 January 2018, Tomlin joined [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on loan in a swap deal with [[Jamie Ward]] moving to Cardiff on loan in return.{{cite news |url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/sport/football/transfer-news/another-deal-done-lee-tomlin-1148423 |title=Another deal done: Lee Tomlin joins Nottingham Forest on loan, as Jamie Ward heads to Cardiff |newspaper=Nottingham Post |author=Paul Taylor |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=1 February 2018}} He scored his first goal for Forest in a 1–1 draw with [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 20 February 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43039999|title=Nottingham Forest 1–1 Reading |publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 February 2018|accessdate=21 February 2018}}. On 18 December 2018, it was announced that Tomlin was training with [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] and would return to the club on loan from 1 January 2019 until the end of the season.{{cite news |url=https://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/sport/football/posh/breaking-lee-tomlin-is-back-at-peterborough-united-1-8744365 |title= Lee Tomlin is back at Peterborough United |newspaper=Peterborough Telegraph |author=Alan Swann |date=18 December 2018 |accessdate=18 December 2018}} However, the move was delayed due to paperwork issues.{{cite news |url=https://www.gazettelive.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/peterborough-lee-tomlin-loan-boro-15625104 |title=Peterborough race against time to sign former Boro playmaker Lee Tomlin before Riverside cup clash |publisher=Gazette Live |last=Vickers |first=Anthony |date=4 January 2019 |accessdate=6 January 2019}} The transfer was eventually completed on 8 January.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46787418 |title=Lee Tomlin: Peterborough United re-sign Cardiff City forward on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 January 2019 |accessdate=8 January 2019}} ==International career== Tomlin was [[Cap (sport)|capped]] two times by the [[England national football C team|England national C team]] in 2009.{{cite book |editor1-first=Mike |editor1-last=Williams |editor2-first=Tony |editor2-last=Williams |title=Non-League Club Directory 2013 |year=2012 |publisher=Tony Williams Publications |location= |isbn=978-1-869833-77-0 |pages=1003, 1005, 1010}} ==Career
